Award.AwardTitle: A Pioneering Study of the Architecture of Ant Nests
Award.AbstractNarration: Because they are below ground, the nests of subterranean ants are largely unseen and unknown. The principle investigator has developed plaster, wax and metal casting methods that have revealed the remarkable variation, beauty and species-typical structure of ant nests. Within these nests, the colony is self-organized such that the youngest workers are generally near the bottom with the brood, and the oldest near or on the surface. Field and laboratory experiments on the Florida harvester ant will address three general questions: (1) How do the ants excavate their nests through self-organization? What behavioral programs operate to create this amazing architecture? (2) Through what cues does the colony organize itself within the nest space? Does the previously detected carbon dioxide gradient provide depth cues to the ants, or do they respond to each other to create the observed spatial arrangement? (3) Do particular features of the architecture, or the architecture as a whole affect colony functions (such as production or efficiency), and if so, through what mechanisms? This is a pioneering study of a crucial, unknown aspect of social insect biology. A cast of an ant nest is an exact physical record of self-organized behavior that can be studied with ease. These experiments will show how a self-organized collective of autonomous agents (ant workers) use simple rules to produce a complex outcome (the nest). The nest casts have and will continue to be displayed in a number of public museums, exposing the public to their wonder and beauty. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in field and laboratory experimentation. Broader impacts of this project derive from the current intense interest in self-organization, in fields spanning from computer science and robotics to a number of large- and small-scale human social and economic phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ants excavate beautiful, complex underground nests in the dark, without a blueprint and without a leader.  About once a year, the Florida harvester ant creates and moves into a new nest in 4 to 6 days, moving up to 10 liters of soil from the depths to the surface in the process.  The ants collect and store seeds in underground chambers, but most seeds are too large to open, and can be eaten only after they germinate.  Germination depends on season and seed species, so that storage represents a gamble by the ants. Workers are born deep in the nest, caring for brood early in life, moving upward and changing tasks as they age, finally foraging during the last 20 days of their lives.  The foraging population is highly seasonal, peaking in early summer, and is regulated by forager mortality, which in turn, is caused by fighting with neighbors.  Middle-aged workers transport materials up and down within the nest by sequential caching. These patterns suggest that the ants "know" their depth within the nest.  Carbon dioxide concentration increases dramatically with depth, suggesting that this might serve as a depth cue for the ants, but experiments showed this was not the case.  Colony life expectancy increases as colonies grow, so that large colonies live 30 years or more.  Metal or plaster casts of the nests of 28 species of ants revealed the large range and size of architectures.


Last Modified: 11/02/2017
Modified by: Walter R Tschinkel

Images (1 of )
  • This is a plaster cast of the nest of a Florida harvester ant. The nest was created in 4 to 6 days by a colony of about 5000 ants who moved 20 kg of soil to make the nest
    Charles F. Badland
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Walter R Tschinkel
    Florida harvester ant nest cast
  • These casts show the range of architectures and sizes among ants.
    Walter R. Tschinkel
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Walter R Tschinkel
    Examples of casts of the nests of several ant species
  • Workers are shown to the same scale as the seeds they collect. All but the smallest seeds are too large for them to open and eat. Therefore, they wait until the seeds germinate in their moist, underground storage chambers, and then consume them.
    Walter R. Tschinkel
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Walter R Tschinkel
    Harvester ant workers in relation to the seeds they collect

About once a year, the Florida harvester ant creates and moves into a new nest in 4 to 6 days, moving up to 10 liters of soil from the depths to the surface in the process. The ants collect and store seeds in underground chambers, but most seeds are too large to open, and can be eaten only after they germinate. Germination depends on season and seed species, so that storage represents a gamble by the ants. Workers are born deep in the nest, caring for brood early in life, moving upward and changing tasks as they age, finally foraging during the last 20 days of their lives. The foraging population is highly seasonal, peaking in early summer, and is regulated by forager mortality, which in turn, is caused by fighting with neighbors. Middle-aged workers transport materials up and down within the nest by sequential caching. These patterns suggest that the ants "know" their depth within the nest. Carbon dioxide concentration increases dramatically with depth, suggesting that this might serve as a depth cue for the ants, but experiments showed this was not the case. Colony life expectancy increases as colonies grow, so that large colonies live 30 years or more. Metal or plaster casts of the nests of 28 species of ants revealed the large range and size of architectures. Last Modified: 11/02/2017 Submitted by: Walter R Tschinkel
